unnormalised: New Delhi: The Ministry of Health & Family Welfare reported a surge in dengue cases across several states, particularly in Kerala, Maharashtra, and West Bengal. As of 16/10/2024, the total number of reported cases stands at 12,500, marking a 20% increase compared to the same period last year. Health officials attribute the rise to prolonged monsoon season and inadequate sanitation in urban areas.
normalised: New Delhi: The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare reported a surge in dengue cases across several states, particularly in Kerala, Maharashtra, and West Bengal. As of sixteenth October two thousand and twenty four, the total number of reported cases stands at twelve thousand five hundred, marking a twenty percent increase compared to the same period last year. Health officials attribute the rise to prolonged monsoon season and inadequate sanitation in urban areas.

unnormalised: Dr. Rajesh Kumar, Director of the National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), emphasized the need for immediate vector control measures. "Aggressive fogging drives and community awareness campaigns are crucial to curb the spread," he stated during a press conference held at AIIMS earlier today. The ministry has allocated Rs. 50 crore to affected states for procuring insecticides and diagnostic kits.

unnormalised: Public health advisories have been issued, urging citizens to eliminate stagnant water sources, use mosquito repellents, and wear full-sleeved clothing. The advisory also recommends seeking prompt medical attention for symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, and joint pain. District-level health officers have been instructed to conduct door-to-door surveys to identify and eliminate mosquito breeding sites.

unnormalised: In response to the crisis, the government has launched a nationwide campaign called "Swachh Bharat Abhiyan: Dengue Mukt Bharat," aiming to improve sanitation and waste management practices. The campaign will involve collaboration between various government departments, NGOs, and local communities. Furthermore, the ministry plans to conduct training programs for healthcare workers on the latest dengue management protocols.

unnormalised: The health ministry urges public cooperation in combating this public health threat. Citizens are encouraged to report any suspected dengue cases to the nearest health center and to follow all preventive measures diligently. The next review meeting is scheduled for 25/10/2024 to assess the effectiveness of the ongoing interventions.
